newsitem.title: UK: UK's Commercial Union interim profits rise.
newsitem.headline: UK's Commercial Union interim profits rise.

text.p: British composite insurance group Commercial Union PLC announced a 25 percent rise in pre-tax operating profits, at constant exchange rates, to 235 million pounds ($381.8 million) in six months to June, 1997, mainly buoyed by a boost in its life insurance business.
The group announced an interim dividend of 12.25 pence a share, up from 11.45 pence in the previous year.
The group's total premium income rose to 4.27 billion pounds ($6.9 billion) from 4.04 billion pounds at constant exchange rates. Commercial Union's earnings per share rose to 21.5 pence from 17.2 p.

John Carter, the chief executive of the group, said a strong increase in life profits combined with a rise in overseas general insurance business more than offset lower general insurance results in the United Kingdom.

Life profits rose 24 percent to 125 million pounds on constant exchange rates with new business in this segment rising to 21 percent. Apart from the UK, life business was also strong in the Netherlands, Poland and Italy.

Carter said the company's general insurance profits rose seven percent to 169 million pounds. The group witnessed a turnaround in the United States, helped by lower weather claims, and also saw profit increases in France and Australia. ($ = 0.615 British Pounds)
